The long-term capital gains (LTCG) on sale of property and other capital assets are taxable mostly after indexation but may be saved through some specific ways. One of the best ways to save tax is through investments in 54EC Bonds, which is commonly known as Capital Gain Bonds as tax deduction is available under section 54EC of the Income Tax Act.
The 54EC bonds are not only AAA rated (Risk free investments), but are backed by the government also, hence the risk factor associated with buying 54EC bonds is mitigated.

Individuals as well as members of HUF can make investments in 54EC bonds. You should invest in 54EC bonds within 6 months of transferring capital assets. Take a look at the benefits of investing in 54EC bonds.

With effect from FY 2018\-19, benefit of investing in 54EC bonds would be available on sale of land or building (residential or commercial). The capital gains 54EC bonds eligible for tax deductions can be issued only by

A sudden influx of cash due to a sale of property or other capital assets can attract a very high tax and can take a huge chunk away from your capital gains. 54 EC Capital Gains bonds are a really good investment option which can save your gains from taxes at the same time provide you a steady return on investment till the 5 year maturity period with very low risk.

The Government will launch Floating Rate Savings Bonds 2020 (Taxable) scheme with an interest rate of 7.15 percent from July 1, 2020. As per RBI, its interest rates would be reset every six months. The launch of the bonds was announced after the withdrawal of Taxable Bonds, offering a fixed interest rate of 7.75 percent, on May 28, 2020.

For the newly launched Floating Rate Savings Bonds 2020, the interest amount is payable every six months and after which the interest rate would be reset. Its first interest rate reset would happen on January 1, 2021.

The change in the interest rate is pegged with the prevailing National Saving Certificate (NSC) rate. That is, the rates would be adjusted as 35 basis points over the prevailing NSC rate.For example, the prevailing NSC rate is 6.8 percent. Now adding another 35 basis points to the NSC rate, i.e. 6.8% + .35% = 7.15%, the interest rate for the Floating Rate Savings Bonds 2020 (payable on January 1, 2021) was decided. Similarly, the new rates would be reset on Jan 1, 2021 depending upon the then NSC rate.

The bonds can be purchased from designated branches of SBI, IDBI, HDFC, and ICICI bank and will be issued only as Bond Ledger Account.The bond can be bought in cash (up to Rs 20,000), demand draft, cheque, or through online payments. While there is no maximum limit for investment, the minimum requirement is only Rs 1,000.
Return from your investments in Floating Rate Savings Bonds 2020 will be added to your income and taxed as per your tax slab.

The bondholder/holders can make a nomination for the bond. The bond will be automatically transferred to the nominee/nominees upon his/her/their death. Meanwhile, it cannot be traded in the market or used as collateral for a loan.

Since the Interest obtained on the bonds is taxable it is not a good option for people in the 30% tax bracket, but for people in lower brackets this can turn out to be a really good investment. Any investor looking for risk-free investments can consider to include the RBI Floating Rate Saving Bonds in their investment plan.

For people in higher tax brackets or more those who are more risk tolerant can consider Corporate Bond Funds plans as they offer higher returns and are more liquid. The funds invest only in high rated PSU and Banking bonds and hence are highly safe but the returns on these funds can be affected by the prevailing interest rate.
